Do electric car dream of software fixes?
 On when their inverte go haywire
 RECALL how Apple’ reputation took a knock aft the firm admitt it had surreptitious hobbl the performance of peope’ iPhon when their batte start deteriorat with age. Toyota now fac similar opprobrium for throttl back the batte of some of it old Priu hybrid cars, to prevent them fry their electronics. The software tweak—perform dur a voluntary recall of Prius sold in America between 2010 and 2014—forc the vehicle to re more on it petrol engine and le on it electric motor/generators. That caus fuel economy to fall and exhaust emission to rise. Priu owners, who bought their hybrid vehicl precise because they were lean and clean, have not been b pleased. 
 
 More gall still, report continue to come in of overheat problem that leave Priu owne in limp-home mode or strand in traffic unable to move. Online forum (see priuschat.com) have been abuzz with tal of woe from afflict drivers. Apparently, owne of vehicl that are out of warranty have fac repair estimat of $3,500 or more. Toyota ha since extend the warranty of the car affected, and promis to reimburse those who have been left out-of-pocket.
 
 Even so, the carmak i now fac litigation ov it recall remedy. A lawsuit brought by one of California’ larg Toyota deale alleg that more than 100 of it custome with Prius that had already receiv the software update have return with the same overheat problem. Toyota disput the allegation and ha sought to have the suit dismissed. A judge ha since rul that the case can go forward, and ha set a date for the trial ear next year.
 
 The source of the trouble i a box of trick und the bonnet known a an inverter. Thi tak the 206-volt direct current (DC) from the Prius’ nickel metal-hydride battery and convert it into the three-phase 500-volt alternat current (AC) nee to drive the car’ two electric motor/generators. (One of these i us to propel the car when operat und battery power, and to assist in recharg the battery when braking; the other’ main job i to keep the battery charged, while suppe supplementary pow to the drive assembly, a well a serv a an electric start for the petrol engine.) Both motor/generator produce mechanical torque when driven by AC electricity—or, when spun backward by an external source (ie, the hybrid’ petrol engine or the wheel dur braking), generate AC electricity.
 
 Manag thi merry-go-round i the job of the invert and it associat electronic-control units. Inside the invert i a hefty circuit board with a bank of heavy-duty switch component call insulated-gate bipolar transistors. These flip the direction of the DC supp from the battery thousand of tim a second, to produce the three-phase AC nee for powe the vehicle’ electric motors. Switch such a heavy current rapid generat a seriou amount of heat. To cope, the invert ha it own glycol-bas cool system.
 
 Thi all work fine in normal conditions. Occasionally, however, a glitch in the inverter’ software let matte get out of hand. Microscopic void then build up in the sold beneath the transistors, caus part to short-circuit or simp to overheat. Eith way, the temperature inside the invert can rise rapidly. If that temperature becom excessive, the transistor get fr and the vehicle shut down completely. More often, the overheat mere caus the current to the invert to be reduced, the instrument panel to light up like a Christma tree, and the vehicle to go into limp-home mode while the cool down.
 
 The quick fix adopt by Toyota ha been to reset the inverter’ software in ord to reduce the likelihood of the transistor be stress unduly. That ha meant lowe the current from the battery and forc the petrol engine to work hard to compensate—hence the high fuel consumption and increas exhaust emissions.
 
 The experience ha baffl many owners. Online que have focus on why so complex a contraption a an inverter/convert i nee anyway. Some have even wonde why the Priu us AC electric motor/generator when perfect good DC motor and alternator have been around for ages? The presumption i that us a DC motor would allow the vehicle to be powe direct from the battery, obviat the ne for an inverter.
 
 Well, not exactly. Electric motors, wheth AC or DC, work by caus a magnetic field in the rotat part (rotor) to interact with a magnetic field in the stationary part (stator) of the machine. Magnetic field can be produc by permanent magnet or by electric current pass through bundl of wir wrapp around an iron core. Whatev the mechanism, all electric motors, wheth their input current i AC or DC, require an alternat current in their stator winde to make their rotor spin.
 
 In a conventional DC motor thi AC current i generat by carbon brush that rub against a split copp r on the motor’ spindle. A it rotates, thi arrangement, call a commutator, chop (ie, rapid connect and disconnects) the direct current to create a crude form of alternat current. Unfortunately, thi caus numerou problems. Friction and electrical arc at the commutator mean the brush must be replac regularly. Arc at the commutator also limit the voltage that can be used, and thu the pow produced. And because of the heavy current cours through a DC motor’ inn windings, the rotor can get extreme hot and become difficult to cool. Conventional DC motors, moreover, require gear box because, while huge at start up, the torque they produce fall off rapid with rotational speed. Finally, DC motor are not particular good at be run backwards, in ord to generate electricity for recharg purposes. At best, they are good for golf cart and fork-lift trucks.
 Hence the “brushless” DC motors, with their transistoris switch in place of mechanical brush and a commutator. These have no brush-relat friction or arcing, and control of the current mean torque can be controll without the ne for multiple gears. Like oth hybrid vehicles, thi i what the Priu uses, though it call them synchronou AC permanent magnet motors. For all intent and purposes, brushle DC motor and synchronou AC motor are essential the same. Both use permanent magnet embedd in their rotor and both ne inverters.
 
 That, though, rais an interest question. Why not go the whole hog and use the output of the transistor to drive what i known a an AC induction motor? That i what Tesla does. An AC induction motor do not ne permanent magnets, and can thu do without the expensive rare-earth metal that are an essential ingredient of modern, high-performance magnets. The answ i that while induction motor are ideal for electric vehicl built for spe (like Teslas), they are not all that efficient when us for potte around town or cruis lazi down the highway. A car and lorr tend to spend 90% of their time us little more than 10% of their maximum power, brushle DC motor are a bett bet for typical hybrid vehicl like the Prius.
